title: Multilingual Clusters and Gender in Nordic Twitter
segmentation: So.
Good morning everyone.
I've got perhaps also an issue regarding the technology, so I created HTML slides and I've been looking at them on Chrome, but we don't have Chrome here, so we'll see what happens with Explorer.
So I'm using Twitter data, and I'm considering multilingualism in Nordic, European context using Twitter data.
A few things I wanted to to think about here.

Looking at a gender as a particular context and to see how multilingualism or language variation might correlate with gender, it's been found, I think many of you probably know from linguistic research that there are small but significant differences according to gender in the use of some grammatical features.
So corpus linguists have found this with textual data and also with social media data, so the frequency of determiners or numerical types or pronouns etc.

So I wanted to consider language at maybe a different level of organization at higher level of discourse organization and kind of consider this question in regards to language choice for users who are multilingual.
And as you know, many users on Twitter are multilingual.
Are there differences between the males and females in terms of what languages they are using and what might be motivating that choice?
I think it provides us perhaps some insight into changing language situation in social media.
So in these slides I have two basic things I want to touch upon.
First of all, explore the extent of language use by gender on Twitter and then in the second part I'm looking at similarities or differences by gender for specific language pairs.
So data collection.
I collected tweets with populated place attributes using three PY which we all know by now.
From the streaming API from November until April, so that's about 530 million tweets.
Of course, most of those are not from the Nordic countries.
So I collected from that data the user names of 160,000 authors of who had published tweets from Nordic Country.
And then, of course you also have to include or at least I included a Greenland, the Pharaohs and all and so this little archipelago between Sweden and Finland.
The reason of course being that the Twitter Place library uses this ISO attribute, so Overland is not considered part of Finland by Twitter.
So the gender disambiguation?
So I induced probability that given names would be of a certain male or female by aggregating information from the statistical offices of the Nordic countries.

So this was depending on the country and they either have a very good availability for the data, so Sweden and Denmark for example, Finland, Norway and Iceland, not quite as much, but I collected name.
Frequency information and then simply calculated the probability.
So this is very simple.
Just yeah, the frequency of a name assigned to males over the frequency that's assigned to to all users and then only accepted.
Then users whose author name included these male or female names is a distinct element.
So in the name attribute with a probability of higher than 0.8.
Alright, a little bit more filtering was done, so once I had these users, so I then downloaded their timelines or up to 32,250 tweets.

And then retained only those users who had at least 50% of their place attributes being within an order country, so that actually filtered out a huge number of users because people are quite mobile and a lot of people were just tweeting when they were traveling to Stockholm or whatever.
Finally, the issue with yeah bots and apps, so this is not really a very sophisticated approach.

But as we've heard in previous days, there are some real problems with automated messages on Twitter, and because I'm looking at language use I only wanted to consider then tweets where we could have a relatively high level of certainty that they were actually using the English language for example, and then so I wanted to eliminate these these apps that send out automated messages.
For example, with weather information or I've been jogging 8 kilometers today or I'm located at this bar or something like that, so I did that by filtering out tweets sources.
Language detection is also quite problematic with Twitter as you know, so I have removed then sequences that can cause problem for some of these algorithms.
So usernames, URLs, hashtags and emojis.
And then relied on 3 way agreement between the native Twitter language algorithm, but also Lang ID, which we all know from from Nicolai yesterday.
And then also the compact language detector too.
So the Chrome script for language detection.
So I found that if there's a 3 way agreement, then it's it's pretty reliable in terms of accurately detecting.
The language, so after that filtering about 25 million tweets by about 45 thousand different authors.
Here we have a map and I'm very sorry to say that in this rendering here with Internet Explorer, it's not visualizing all the nice things that I did on the map.
So you have to ask me for the slides and then I'll send them to.
You have to look at them.
In Chrome.
There's some JavaScript rendering problem.
ASOBAL skip over that.
But so now we have these users that we've identified as a male and female, and we want to look at the proportion of.
Tweets in all of the languages that have been detected in the database.
So there are 87 of them and then to see whether or not the language is used more by males or females.
And this was done for each language by simply conducting a test of population means for the mean proportion of tweets in that language.
Also did a bit of boot strapping.
Of course the test prerequisite is that you have equal variance and then, especially for languages that are not very frequent in the data set, that prerequisite is not fulfilled.
However, if you do a lot of bootstrapping then that can be relatively reliable data central limit theorem.
So I'm showing the 28 most frequently occurring languages in the data.
Here we see them for Iceland and the way to interpret this.
So here on the bottom, I'm afraid you can't read it very well from here, but these are the languages.
This is the T statistic.
The blue bars indicate that it's the language is more used by males.
The reddish parts that it's more used by females.
The red lines here indicate.
Then yeah, P value of 0.05 and then we have the confidence interval.
So you can see that for Iceland there are not a huge number of users.
So we don't really have differences that we could consider extremely striking in terms of male female differences for the languages.
We could point out that, for example, the national language Icelandic seems to be favored by males.
English seems to be slightly favored by females for Iceland.
I'm moving out to Norway.
We've got yeah larger data set here.
And the thing that we can notice here is that English is quite strikingly female.
Here, females are using a lot more English than males in Norway.

They are also using a lot more Spanish and we see that the Norwegian language so Norwegian has then two official written varieties, so bokmal is kind of standard equivalent to Danish and then Nynorsk.
But both of these standard varieties are preferred or written more frequently by by males, so that's kind of interesting.
Move.
Going on to Denmark, we see a similar pattern, so the national language Danish is very, very male.
English is very female.
Some of the other languages will.
Note that, for example, Arabic and Farsi are quite Mail here as well.
Do not have Sweden.

The picture gets a little bit different here, so English which had been female in the previous countries has now become Mail for Sweden and the national language of Swedish is very very female here, so females are using a lot more of the national language in Sweden.
Probably the most significant difference here is for Arabic.
It's very very male.
In Sweden.
I'll get to that in just a second so.
And finally, Finland has a pattern which is similar to that of Sweden.
We have English being more male Swedish, excuse me, finish being much more female.
So this data.
We can summarize.
Males are using a lot more, for example Arabic, Farsi and Turkish females are using a lot more Thai tagalong, Japanese and Russian.
These facts may represent some gender differences in patterns of migration to the Nordic countries.
So recently, yeah, there's been a lot of migration to the Nordic sorta Europe overall, and it may be the case that so males in the Nordic countries are taking are marrying people from Southeast Asia.
That might account for the gender balance for some of these Asian languages regarding the national languages and English.
Yeah, we have kind of a the Western Nordics.
The national languages are more male and the English is more female.
Whereas in Sweden, Finland the national languages are more female.
An English is a bit more Mail.
That is kind of interesting.
And then I'm suggesting that this might represent some incipient language shift in a lab.
Bovian, sociolinguistics sense, but let's.

Yeah, the idea is that of course that in a changing language situation than females are more likely to use features that are representative of language change, and it may simply be the case that because Sweden and Finland have larger language communities or have been perhaps a bit more isolated from English language communities, their language shift is occurring a little bit more recently.
Alright, so the next thing I want to look at very briefly is then by Anne Multilingualism, so that was an overview of language by gender overall, and I'm just going to go through this very quickly.
So criteria for my multilingualism, someone I decided is a multilingual if at least 10% of their tweets are in a language they are said to use.
The language of 10% of tweets are in that language, so if at least 2 languages and their multilingual.
In this data, males are more BI and multilingual than females.
For all of the Nordic countries, so not by a lot, but.
And to create networks of BI and multilingual's.
To quantify the strength between the individual languages, put a contingency contingency table of the number of users who are then.
So this would represent the number of users who are speaking to two languages than one language but not the other.
And then neither of those two languages, although they are bilingual.
And then from this we can calculate.
A Phi coefficient.
This is then, of course, the same as Pearson's product moment coefficient, but for binary variables.
And then this high coefficient will then qualify on a scale from minus one to one.
The strength between any two individual languages.
So.
Yeah, very brief.
Here's some nice things.
That if you want to take a look at the slides, I'd be happy to send them to you, but I've kind of summarize all the information here.
You can see the exact number of tweets, the number of users, the Phi coefficient, and then interesting here is that the bilinguals.

There are some differences, for example in the mean tweet length for bilingual users, and I found and this is something that is still work in progress, but it seems that bilingual users are writing in general longer tweets than users who are monolingual.
So here is Norway.
Denmark is, this is what the connection looks like.
Sweden of course we have more users and then most of them are writing in Swedish.
That's what we see here in Finland.
A little bit fewer.
And then OK, so I guess I don't have really time for this, but to yeah Z score to compare these five values was calculated.
And then you can kind of.
See which are the most male and female language pairs, so Russian and Ukrainian is then used mainly by females, so English and then Japanese, English and Turkish Nynorsk in Oregon.
That's kind of interesting as well.
And then the most Mail we have, English and Polish and English and Dutch and then some other ones as well.
So, um, yeah, males are a little bit more bilingual, or comparison of five values can support some socio linguistic interpretation.
But I mean if you change the parameters just a little bit then the results are quite different.
So I think I need to collect a little bit more.
Evidence for their so thanks, these people help me with the data giving me some name lists, so that's all.
I have thank you.
